newsitem.title: CANADA: Toronto stocks end down on rate jitters, Bre-X.
newsitem.headline: Toronto stocks end down on rate jitters, Bre-X.

text.p: Toronto stocks ended weaker on Wednesday, shedding Tuesday's gains as interest rate jitters and the Bre-X Minerals saga dragged the market lower.
The TSE 300 Composite Index fell 51.23 points to 5849.14 in brisk turnover of 90.7 million shares worth C$1.36 billion ($985 million).
Declining stocks outpaced advances 549 to 400, with 292 issues unchanged.

The key index lost slightly more than the 50.15 points it gained in Tuesday's session. "The market was spooked by the fear of rising (U.S.) interest rates," said Ira Katzin, an investment adviser with RBC Dominion Securities.
On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average sank 94 points on investor fears that a further hike in U.S. interest rates would signal a slowing economy and weaker growth in corporate profits.

"Of course, Canadian rates would have to follow suit or the Canadian dollar would collapse," Katzin said. The Canadian currency ended firmer on Wednesday, but analysts expected the recent weak trend to continue if Friday's U.S. payrolls data showed signs of inflation.
The other major weight on the Toronto market was Bre-X Minerals Ltd. and its controversial Busang gold discovery.
Shares in the Canadian gold prospector resumed trading on Wednesday, but massive trading volumes again overwhelmed a creaky computer system on the Toronto exchange.
Bre-X fell 0.65 to 3.20 on massive volume of 11.7 million shares before trading was stopped due to technical problems.
Trading was not interrupted on the Montreal Exchange where Bre-X closed down 0.35 at 3.15 on 6.1 million shares.
* Bema Gold Corp. rose 0.70 to 10.30 on 1.8 million shares after the mining firm released favorable resource estimates for a Chilean gold project.
* Northern Telecom Ltd. was the top loser, falling 3 to 89 on 370,400 shares.
* Conglomerate Canadian Pacific Ltd. dropped 0.80 to close at 32.55 on 1.2 million shares.
* Software maker Cognos Inc. led net gainers, climbing 2.35 to 39.50 on 62,000 shares.
